definitions.definition: a hard, usually clear, substance used, for example, for making windows and bottles

I cut myself on a piece of **broken glass**.
frosted/toughened glass
a glass bottle/jar
sliding **glass doors**
a glass roof/dome/panel
The vegetables are grown under glass *(= in a )*.
He could see the light through the frosted glass.
She cut her foot on some glass.
The books were all behind glass.
The floor was littered with fragments of broken glass.
We grow fruit under glass.
We watched the Venetian craftsmen blowing glass.
the sound of breaking glass

examples.text: He poured orange juice into a glass.
a champagne/beer glass
a shot glass
a pint glass
the red liquid in his glass
beer in a pint glass
a set of crystal glasses

The waiter filled their glasses.

a glass of milk

definitions.definition: two lenses in a frame that rests on the nose and ears. People wear glasses in order to be able to see better or to protect their eyes from bright light.
definitions.labels: North American English alsoold-fashioned or formalinformalespecially in British English

examples.text: a **pair of glasses**
reading glasses
**I wear glasses** for driving.
We keep all our glass and china in this cupboard.
She has a fine collection of Bohemian glass.

definitions.definition: a protecting cover made of glass on a watch, picture or photograph frame, fire alarm, etc.

examples.text: In case of emergency, break the glass and press the button.

definitions.definition: used to refer to the attitude of somebody who always looks at the bad things in a situation rather than the good ones

examples.text: For me the glass is half-empty.
If you start to look at things with a glass half-empty mentality, your problems soon pile up.

definitions.definition: used to refer to the attitude of somebody who always looks at the good things in a situation rather than the bad ones

examples.text: My glass is always half-full.
She always looks on the bright side—she's a glass half-full kind of person.

definitions.definition: you should not criticize other people, because they will easily find ways of criticizing you
to hold up your glass and wish somebody happiness, good luck, etc. before you drink

wordOrigin: Old English glæs, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch glas and German Glas.
